Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WB5-XV21-JC8S-D2TH-00000-00Panel mulls antitrust aid for news outlets2019-06-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:05ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B010Panel mulls antitrust aid for news outletsMarcy Gordon

1) Matt Schruers, from left, of the Computer and Communications Industry Association, David Pitofsky, center, general counsel of News Corp., and Kevin Riley, editor of the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, right, are sworn in before the House judiciary panel. PHOTO: Cliff Owen/Associated Press

WASHINGTON - Members of both parties Tuesday suggested legislation might be necessary for the financially struggling U.S. news industry as lawmakers began a bipartisan investigation into the market dominance of Silicon Valley companies. At a hearing of the House Judiciary Committee's antitrust panel, news media associations accused the tech companies of jeopardizing the industry's economic survival by putting news content on their platforms without fairly compensating them. "This is the first significant antitrust investigation undertaken by Congress in decades," said Rep. David Cicilline, D-R.I., the subcommittee's chairman, at the start of the hearing.

The investigation is long overdue, he said, and Congress must determine whether the antitrust laws "are equipped for the competition problems of our modern economy." Cicilline noted the steep layoffs in the news industry in recent years, saying the dominant position of the online platforms in the advertising market has created "an economic catastrophe for news publishers, forcing them to cut back on their investments in quality journalism." At the same time, he said, tech platforms that are gateways to news online "have operated with virtual immunity from the antitrust laws." As a partial solution, Cicilline proposed legislation to establish an antitrust exemption that would allow news companies to band together to negotiate revenue rates with big tech platforms. He called it "a life support measure, not the remedy for long-term health" of the news business. The senior Republican on the full committee, Rep. Doug Collins of Georgia, said he backs Cicilline's proposal. Addressing the broader question of antitrust, however, he said, "Big is not necessarily bad," adding that lawmakers need to proceed cautiously. The head of an association that represents technology and telecommunication companies said the government scrutiny of successful companies is appropriate. However, an antitrust exemption for the news industry wouldn't solve the problem, said Matt Schruer, vice president of the Computer and Communications Industry Association. Schruer said exemptions news publishers received in the past to deal with former competitors like radio and television have not worked. "The results were fewer choices for readers and less competition among news outlets," Schruer said. But David Chavern, president of the News Media Alliance representing some 2,000 news organizations of all sizes and types, called an antitrust exemption "the lightest-touch option on the table." "There's a real urgency in the industry. We're at crisis point now," Chavern said. Stepping ahead of the criticism, Google's vice president of news Richard Gringas said the company has "worked for many years to be a collaborative and supportive technology and advertising partner to the news industry." "Every month, Google News and Google Search drive over 10 billion clicks to publishers' websites, which drive subscriptions and significant ad revenue," he said in a statement Tuesday. In a Capitol steeped in partisanship, inflamed by special counsel Robert Mueller's report and Democrats' intensifying probes of President Donald Trump, Congress' new investigation of tech market power stands out. Not only is it bipartisan, but it's also the first such review by Congress of a sector that for more than a decade has enjoyed haloed status and a light touch from federal regulators. With regulators at the Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission apparently pursuing antitrust investigations of Facebook, Google, Apple and Amazon, and several state attorneys general exploring bipartisan action of their own, the tech industry finds itself in a precarious moment - with the dreaded M-word increasingly used to describe their way of doing business. Cicilline has flatly called them monopolies. The Justice Department's antitrust chief suggested in a speech Tuesday he might take a broad view of harm to competition and take into account quality factors such as the threat to privacy instead of only whether a company's dominant market position results in higher prices. "Price effects alone do not provide a complete picture of market dynamics, especially in digital markets in which the profit-maximizing price is zero," Assistant Attorney General Makan Delrahim said, according to a transcript of his speech in Tel Aviv, Israel, provided by the department. Politicians on the left and right have differing gripes about the tech giants. Some complain of aggressive conduct that squashes competition. Others perceive a political bias or tolerance of extremist content. Still others are upset by the industry's harvesting of personal data. Several Democratic presidential candidates think they have the solution: breaking up the companies on antitrust grounds. Cicilline has called that "a last resort," but the idea has currency with both major political parties, including at the White House. Trump noted the huge fines imposed by European regulators on the biggest tech companies. "We are going to be looking at them differently," he said in an interview Monday on CNBC. "We should be doing what (the Europeans) are doing," Trump said. "Obviously, there is something going on in terms of monopoly." The tech giants have mostly declined to comment on the antitrust investigations. Google has said scrutiny from lawmakers and regulators "often improves our products and the policies that govern them," and that in some areas, such as data protection, laws need to be updated. Facebook executives have been calling broadly for regulation while explicitly rejecting the idea of breaking up "a successful American company."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X20-WN21-JBV1-X2BM-00000-00Panel steps up US antitrust probe with Big Tech request2019-09-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:05ZLexisNexisPanel steps up US antitrust probe with Big Tech requestWashington, Sept 13 2019

A US congressional panel stepped up its antitrust probe of four Big Tech firms on Friday with a wide-ranging request for documents on their business operations.

The House Judiciary Committee sent letters to Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook seeking detailed information about their various business segments and any "executive communication" that discusses potential anti-competitive conduct or prior investigations.

Judiciary Committee chairman Jerrold Nadler said the documents would give "a better understanding of the degree to which these intermediaries enjoy market power, how they are using that market power (and) whether they are using their market power in ways that have harmed consumers."

The move ramps up a congressional inquiry into the dominant tech platforms at the same time US regulators and state officials are looking into potential antitrust violations.

Representative David Cicilline, who heads the antitrust subcommittee probing the firms, said the latest request is "an important milestone in this investigation" and that the panel would be seeking to "ensure that the internet is an engine for opportunity for everyone, not just a select few gatekeepers."

US Justice Department enforcers earlier this year launched a review of major online platforms to determine if they have "stifled" innovation or reduced competition.

Last week, 50 attorneys general announced a probe into whether Google abused its power in the online ecosystem at the expense of rivals or consumers.

That followed a separate investigation into Facebook announced earlier in the month by a coalition of US states.

The antitrust actions come against a backdrop of declining public trust in big online firms, and fines levied against Facebook and Google over privacy violations.

The House panel said it wants key emails and documents from top executives including Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, Apple CEO Tim Cook and the top executives of Google, its parent firm Alphabet and its YouTube video service.

Documents sought also include memoranda, studies and white papers on various business units and acquisitions by the big firms.

The committee, which announced its probe in June, said it wants the documents by October 14.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X2P-CJ81-DYTM-90VC-00000-00Panel Steps Up US Antitrust Probe With Big Tech Request.2019-09-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:05ZLexisNexisPanel Steps Up US Antitrust Probe With Big Tech Request.

A US congressional panel stepped up its antitrust probe of four Big Tech firms on Friday with a wide-ranging request for documents on their business operations.

The House Judiciary Committee sent letters to Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook seeking detailed information about their various business segments and any "executive communication" that discusses potential anti-competitive conduct or prior investigations.

Judiciary Committee chairman Jerrold Nadler said the documents would give "a better understanding of the degree to which these intermediaries enjoy market power, how they are using that market power (and) whether they are using their market power in ways that have harmed consumers."

The move ramps up a congressional inquiry into the dominant tech platforms at the same time US regulators and state officials are looking into potential antitrust violations.

Representative David Cicilline, who heads the antitrust subcommittee probing the firms, said the latest request is "an important milestone in this investigation" and that the panel would be seeking to "ensure that the internet is an engine for opportunity for everyone, not just a select few gatekeepers."

US Justice Department enforcers earlier this year launched a review of major online platforms to determine if they have "stifled" innovation or reduced competition.

Last week, 50 attorneys general announced a probe into whether Google abused its power in the online ecosystem at the expense of rivals or consumers.

That followed a separate investigation into Facebook announced earlier in the month by a coalition of US states.

The antitrust actions come against a backdrop of declining public trust in big online firms, and fines levied against Facebook and Google over privacy violations.

The House panel said it wants key emails and documents from top executives including Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, Apple CEO Tim Cook and the top executives of Google, its parent firm Alphabet and its YouTube video service.

Documents sought also include memoranda, studies and white papers on various business units and acquisitions by the big firms.

The committee, which announced its probe in June, said it wants the documents by October 14.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y8B-1P11-DY08-32FR-00000-00Panorama - 02:08 AM GMT2020-02-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:05ZLexisNexisU.K. NATIONALNewsPanorama - 02:08 AM GMT

Panorama investigates what propelled the success of Amazon and Jeff Bezos in a quarter of a century and is there is a dark side to love for the corporate giant.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

could impact the ability listen to what they are telling us, listen to their concerns and make sure you offer a safe, great working environment and that you pay a decent wage. Two men have been arrested in connection with a fire at Amazon's warehouse in Staffordshire. Six crews were sent to tackle the blaze in Rugeley.

An Amazon worker has been jailed for four years after starting a fire at the company's Staffordshire warehouse, causing #8 million of damage. The Rugeley centre has been hit by fire seven times since 2014. Five were started deliberately. These images were taken during one fire, by warehouse security cameras. Here, a firefighter is surrounded by thick smoke. My fear is - I come to work one day, and I don't go home. Theft by employees was a motive for some of the fires. People were setting fires to steal items from the building. As everyone is running out the fire exits, they pre-dump the stuff by the doors and pick it up, chuck it in the car on the way out. He says this staff break room had two fire exits, one to the warehouse, one to a stairwell. Shortly after a fire in 2016, the warehouse exit was padlocked shut. He says it remained locked for several weeks and believes it was done to prevent theft. All Amazon were concerned about is the items being pinched. If there was a fire at the bottom of that stairwell, people would not be able to get out. They would die. They are not thinking of the risks - it's unforgivable. When you come across a fire door, you are trying to open the door, it's padlocked. You now have people piling up behind you, you then find yourself unable to escape. In the smoke - it's killing you. Amazon says safety is its priority. The fire door was taken out of operation when room occupancy was reduced. The exit sign was not immediately taken down, which was an error that was quickly rectified. It says the remaining fire door fully complied with all applicable fire safety regulations. FUTURISTIC MUSIC PLAYS The owner and founder of Amazon, Jeff Bezos! Jeff Bezos has limitless ambitions. He is even planning a mission to the moon. Do you think we will ever have Amazon fulfilment centres on the moon? That's a very...good question. LAUGHTER I haven't really contemplated that. We will start out delivering, you know, liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen, it's going to be a small selection. Fair enough! But, but a very important one. Amazon is now at the forefront of the big-tech revolution.

urn:contentItem:5Y8B-1P11-DY08-32RB-00000-00Panorama - 02:10 AM GMT2020-02-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:05ZLexisNexisU.K. REGIONAL TVNewsPanorama - 02:10 AM GMT

Panorama investigates what propelled the success of Amazon and Jeff Bezos in a quarter of a century and is there is a dark side to love for the corporate giant.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

by fire seven times since 2014. Five were started deliberately. These images were taken during one fire, fully complied with all applicable fire safety regulations. FUTURISTIC MUSIC PLAYS The owner and founder of Amazon, Jeff Bezos!

But, but a very important one. Amazon is now at the forefront of the big-tech revolution. Last summer, in Las Vegas, it invited the world's leading tech companies to showcase their latest inventions. Amazon made nearly $12 billion profit in 2019. Back on Earth, it is now using that spectacular wealth to buy into other lucrative markets. Markets that offer opportunities to learn even more about us. They don't expand into industries so that they can make a little bit of money, they move into industries so that they can collect a lot of data. And as they collect more data, they find ways to use it. Introducing Ring, the world's most advanced door bell. The Ring video door bell brings convenience, monitoring and security to your most valuable asset, your home. Amazon spent $840 million two years ago, buying video door bell manufacturer Ring, giving it a foothold into the home security industry. Ring makes it convenient to see and speak with whomever is at your front door. Tony Kirk was caught on a Ring device in the early hours of the morning and he has recently been convicted of attempted burglary and attempting to gain entry to the car. Suffolk Police has embraced Ring's crime-fighting potential. I am a convert, I do firmly believe that... Utopia, for me, is if every resident had this, or an equivalent form of technology. This has the power to eradicate or certainly get towards that utopian position around residential-based crime. They have joined forces with Amazon, who have given them around 1,000 of the door bells free of charge, to hand out to residents in Ipswich. I had a gentleman knock on the door. Who... From Suffolk Constabulary. And he just said, "We have put you down "for one of these Ring door bells." And, erm... "So if you want one, you will get one." Giving out free door bells is encouraging other residents to buy them. Other residents in Suffolk, I think, are becoming more and more aware of the benefits and are purchasing in their own right, which is encouraging to see. You have Amazon in partnership with police departments, who have basically turned policemen into Avon salespeople

success when it comes to Labour organising. This internal Amazon video was leaked in 2018. It shows managers how to deal with unions. You will learn about the warning signs most commonly associated with early union organising.

We are removed from site by security, whenever we venture over into that car park area. That is a very good question. I haven't really contemplated that. We will start out delivering you know, liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen, it will be a small selection. Fair enough! But a very important one. Amazon is now at the forefront of the big tech revolution. Last summer in Las Vegas, it invited the world's leading tech companies to showcase their latest inventions. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y7C-9011-JBH6-C19T-00000-00Panorama - 9:25 PM GMT2020-02-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:05ZLexisNexisU.K. REGIONAL TVNewsPanorama - 9:25 PM GMT

Panorama investigates what propelled the success of Amazon and Jeff Bezos in a quarter of a century and is there is a dark side to love for the corporate giant.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

amount of data that's being created. This data collection is extremely important to this business model. It's extremely hard to do. Convincing people to just deploy something like this in their home is kind of, you know, it's a brilliant trick to achieve that.

Whoever owns, collects the data, right. If you have access to it and writes to data then you are king. It's all about the data. Everything. -- rights. Amazon is transforming our lives. In a quarter of a century it has gone from three people in a garage to nearly 800,000 worldwide. Jeff Bezos is said to have a personal fortune of $125 billion. Domination was on Jeff's mind from the beginning. It seemed like a weird idea when we started out because Amazon was tiny and e-commerce as a share of the economy was tiny. So to really feel like you were going to conquer the world through this miniature business seemed a little bit funny. But, yes, domination was very much the idea. What does it mean for a company to have so much knowledge about us that it can use that knowledge to actually shape our behaviour? That is an extraordinary kind of power that has never before existed. In the US, regulators are investigating Amazon's size and power. Jeff Bezos says he welcomes scrutiny. On his company's use of our data, he thinks that's up to us to decide. Earning trust with customers is a valuable business asset and if you mistreat their data they will know, they will figure it out. Customers are very smart. You should never underestimate customers. We have to earn our customers' trust every day. The company is a function of winning back trust. People don't have to come back to Amazon to shop. We have the responsibility as a company to build that trust every day and I think that is accountability and we're working hard on it every day. Former Amazon insiders say it's time for Amazon and all the big tech companies to take more responsibility for the future they're helping to create. We as a tech community are being faced with, I think, a really big existential challenge, which is, do we ultimately value the growth of our economic engines more than we value the underlying moral underpinnings of the world around us? So, technology has to be actively substantial part of the early system that allowed them to come into existence. So I feel responsibility because of that. On the one hand, I'm proud of what it became. But it also scares me. It's funny to think of the technology that would have been involved in or a well's 1984, which was basically, OK, there is a little camera on your wall and probably there is a whole lot of analog tape reels that are spinning somewhere. I mean, that's nothing now, that's an amateur operation. Amazon has been collecting this data since 1996 on hundreds of millions of people. -- George Orwell's 1984. It's sinister. It's sinister city it exists and I don't know where it will go. Companies come and go and pick companies that are the shiniest and most important of any era, you wait a few decades and they're gone. And at your job is to make sure that you delay that date? I would love for it to be after I'm dead! LAUGHTER

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y7C-9011-JBH6-C18Y-00000-00Panorama - 9:25 PM GMT2020-02-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:05ZLexisNexisU.K. REGIONAL TVNewsPanorama - 9:25 PM GMT

Panorama investigates what propelled the success of Amazon and Jeff Bezos in a quarter of a century and is there is a dark side to love for the corporate giant.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

amount of data that's being created. This data collection is extremely important to this business model. It's extremely hard to do. Convincing people to just deploy something like this in their home is kind of, you know, it's a brilliant trick to achieve that.

Whoever owns, collects the data, right. If you have access to it and writes to data then you are king. It's all about the data. Everything. -- rights. Amazon is transforming our lives. In a quarter of a century it has gone from three people in a garage to nearly 800,000 worldwide. Jeff Bezos is said to have a personal fortune of $125 billion. Domination was on Jeff's mind from the beginning. It seemed like a weird idea when we started out because Amazon was tiny and e-commerce as a share of the economy was tiny. So to really feel like you were going to conquer the world through this miniature business seemed a little bit funny. But, yes, domination was very much the idea. What does it mean for a company to have so much knowledge about us that it can use that knowledge to actually shape our behaviour? That is an extraordinary kind of power that has never before existed. In the US, regulators are investigating Amazon's size and power. Jeff Bezos says he welcomes scrutiny. On his company's use of our data, he thinks that's up to us to decide. Earning trust with customers is a valuable business asset and if you mistreat their data they will know, they will figure it out. Customers are very smart. You should never underestimate customers. We have to earn our customers' trust every day. The company is a function of winning back trust. People don't have to come back to Amazon to shop. We have the responsibility as a company to build that trust every day and I think that is accountability and we're working hard on it every day. Former Amazon insiders say it's time for Amazon and all the big tech companies to take more responsibility for the future they're helping to create. We as a tech community are being faced with, I think, a really big existential challenge, which is, do we ultimately value the growth of our economic engines more than we value the underlying moral underpinnings of the world around us? So, technology has to be actively involved in these types of moral discussions, period. I built a substantial part of the early system that allowed them to come into existence. So I feel responsibility because of that. On the one hand, I'm proud of what it became. But it also scares me. It's funny to think of the technology that would have been involved in or a well's 1984, which was basically, OK, there is a little camera on your wall and probably there is a whole lot of analog tape reels that are spinning somewhere. I mean, that's nothing now, that's an amateur operation. Amazon has been collecting this data since 1996 on hundreds of millions of people. -- George Orwell's 1984. It's sinister. It's sinister city it exists and I don't know where it will go. Companies come and go and pick companies that are the shiniest and most important of any era, you wait a few decades and they're gone. And at your job is to make sure that you delay that date? I would love for it to be after I'm dead! LAUGHTER

It's funny to think of the technology that would have been involved in or a well's 1984, which was basically, OK, there is a little camera on your wall and probably there is a whole lot of analog tape reels that are spinning somewhere. I mean, that's nothing now, that's an amateur operation. Amazon has been collecting this data since 1996 on hundreds of millions of people. -- George Orwell's 1984. It's sinister. It's sinister city it exists and I don't know where it will go. Companies come and go and pick companies that are the shiniest and most important of any era, you wait a few decades and they're gone. And at your job is to make sure that you delay that date? I would love for it to be after I'm dead! LAUGHTER

He says this stuff break room had two fire exits, one to the warehouse and one to a stairwell. Shortly after a fire in 2016, the warehouse exit was padlocked shut. He says it remains locked for several weeks and believes it was done to prevent theft. All Amazon says the remaining fire door fully complied with all applicable fire safety regulations. The founder of Amazon, Jeff Bezos! Jeff Bezos has limitless ambitions. He is even planning commission the moon. Do you think we will ever have Amazon fulfilment centres on the moon? That is a very good question. I haven't really contemplated that. We will start out delivering you know, liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen, it will be a small selection. Fair enough! But a very important one. Amazon is now at the forefront of the big tech revolution. Last summer in Las Vegas, it invited the world's leading tech companies to showcase their latest inventions. Amazon made nearly $12 billion profit in 2019. Back on Earth, it is now using that spectacular wealth to buy into other collect more data, they find ways to use it. Introducing Ring, the world's most advanced door bell. The buying video door bell manufacturer Ring, giving it a foothold into the home security industry. Ring makes it convenient to see and speak with whoever is at your front door. Tony Kirk was caught on a Ring device in the early hours of the morning and has recently been convicted of burglary and attempted to gain entry into the car. Suffolk police has embraced the crime-fighting potential of Ring. I am a convert, I do firmly believe that the utopia for me is if every resident had this or equivalent, this has the power to eradicate or certainly get towards that utopian position around residential based crime. They have joined forces with Amazon, who have given them around 1,000 of the door bell is free of charge to hand out to residents in Ipswich. I had a gentleman knock on the door. Everything. -- rights. Amazon is transforming our lives. In a quarter of a century it has gone from three people in a garage to of $125 billion. Domination was on Jeff's mind from the beginning. It seemed like a weird idea when we started out because Amazon was tiny and e-commerce as a share of the economy was tiny. So to really feel like you were going to conquer the world through this miniature business seemed a little bit funny. But, yes, domination was very much the idea.
